fields.description:
10:40:50 AM Matt Quail: CRITICAL url-based timeout on logged-in dashoard https://atlaseye-qa.atlassian.com/atlaseye/?%40asv=cru&view=cru&max=30&timeout=50000 gives a timeout of 50s and a timeout msg, but the page-produced is 13363ms. I said "give it 50s" and it returned in 13s?
10:42:15 AM Matt Quail: CRITICAL: the timeout on the main dashboard needs tweeking. Don't know what it currently is, but my paged-produced times for https://atlaseye-qa.atlassian.com/atlaseye?max=30&view=cru&@asv=cru (4 starred repositories, 3 starred users) were
4124ms 4125ms 3607ms
and I got the timeout msg on all of them.
Pressing "try longer" meant I (eventually) got a non-timedout page in 19352ms.
I wouldn't have wanted to wait 19s, but I would have waited 8-10s to get more than 4s of data.
my suggestion: timeout should be 8s
10:45:34 AM Matt Quail: @anna ack, seems cru-data is the slow stream in this case, jira and commits are faster than the timeout
10:52:05 AM Seb Ruiz: MINOR: it would be nice to show some feedback after clicking "try for longer" in the activity stream. atm i'm forced to guess when the page is loaded again
10:52:58 AM Matt Quail: WEIRD (timeout bug) I get a timeout msg on the commits page https://atlaseye-qa.atlassian.com/atlaseye/changelog?max=30&view=fe&@asv=fe but  not the allactivity page https://atlaseye-qa.atlassian.com/atlaseye/changelog?max=30&view=all&@asv=all even though the latter includes the former (may just be a timing when-i-happend-to-click-it problem)
fields.summary: Improvements to page timeboxing

fields.description:
If you upload a file via rest to rest-service/reviews-v1/CR-1/addFile and subsequently modify the file and upload it again, a new file is added to the review. 

If you do this via the crucible UI, it will be added as a new revision on the existing file. 

!dupe.jpg! 

The screenshot above shows upgrade_0.sql was uploaded via REST and upload_36.sql was uploaded via the crucible UI. The REST API should have the same behaviour.
fields.summary: REST addFile service creates duplicate files when uploading a file with the same name twice

fields.description:
When a reviewer is deleted from a review, we only seem to store a username.

If we had more information to hand we could provide richer details - when removed, by whom, why?

Additionally we could place the circle/slash over the reviewers avatar rather than using a john doe. This would provide a lot more information without requiring and viewer action, especially if there are three of four folks removed from a review.
fields.summary: Store more data about deleted users

fields.description:
Since the inclusion of iframes to house panel contents to speed up page loads, a regression has emerged where the slider no longer works when the cursor is dragged over iframed content.

This is a known issue in jQuery and they have no immediate plan to fix it.

Lets not let that stop us!
fields.summary: jQuery slider doesn't work over an iframe

fields.description:
Today I accidentally deleted a Crucible project.  The Crucible admin screen listing the projects looks like this:

!crucibleadmin.png!

Not thinking too hard, I saw what I thought was a link beginning with "Edit" and clicked it.  Then my brain catches up, saying "Hang on, doesn't that say..", and the browser refreshes; URL {{admin/projectOperation.do?op=Delete&id=83}}, and just like that my project is gone.

Aarrghh!!

Might I suggest:

 - Don't put the links so close together that they are indistinguishable.
 - For operations as drastic as delete there must be a confirmation screen.
 - Follow browser conventions: buttons are for POSTS which are for state-changing operations, links are for GETs which are for idempotent operations. Users implicitly understand this. Crawlers and prefetchers absolutely rely on this.

In short, the "Delete" link should be far away from the "Edit" link, should go to a separate confirmation page with a "Delete" *button*, which does the final deed.
fields.summary: 1mm difference between editing and deleting a Crucible project

fields.description: We keep running into what appears to be classloader issues with REST plugin modules.  I posted the details initially over in the user forum: http://forums.atlassian.com/thread.jspa?threadID=38374&tstart=0.  Simple use cases work correctly, but other scenarios like an invalid request or throwing an exception from your service results in ClassCastException or NoClassDefFoundError.
fields.summary: REST modules and classloader problems

fields.description:
Cru's a pretty keyboard heavy app. but one of the fairly major omission is the ability to submit the comment form using the keyboard. Tab Tab Enter doesn't actually work for me (FF) for some reason.

Some candidate for key combos to do this:
* Accesskey + S : This is the Atlassian standard for submitting a form and used by JIRA, Connie & Bamboo and I reckon to be the preferred option. PITA for Opera users, but then you can't please everyone
* Ctrl + Enter : I think IDEA and maybe some desktop apps do this.
fields.summary: Keyboard shortcut to submit a comment textarea

fields.description:
Take a look at the review: https://www.limewire.org/fisheye/cru/LWCR-530 .  Comments on some files (such as RRProcessingQueue) aren't showing up as inline comments -- they only appear when viewing comments above the file.  This is a major issue for us.  The review is generated by uploading a diff -u patch.

I had thought the pattern was with fully deleted files -- but I tested it out on another review (also from a diff -u uploaded patch), but those show up fine.  I'm not sure what's unique about this review, but something is going very wrong.
fields.summary: Comments not showing up when "inline comments"

fields.description:
It seems that the permissions listed in the "Edit Permission Scheme" admin views table has no specific order.

So how about listing them in alphabetical order or better in a logical order (like "Create" as permission for the initial state comes first and "Close" / "Abandon" as permission for the final states come last)?
fields.summary: Sort permissions listed in the table of the "Edit Permission Scheme" admin view

fields.description:
1. age annotation colour gradation is linear, but should be logarithmic. This would allow more differentiation of newer code.

2. opportunity to have more interaction between age / author annotation and the "legend". the annotation under the cursor should be hilighted in the legend.
fields.summary: improvements to file history page

fields.description:
When uploading a patch for precommit review (not sure what happens when creating a review from FishEye), removed files don't show up as red in the left nav.  Since new files are green, I'd think removed files should be red.  The patch (in unified form) looks like this when a file is removed:

Index: path/to/a/file.extension
===================================================================
RCS file: path/to/a/file.extension
diff -N path/to/a/file.extension
--- path/to/a/file.extension	27 Mar 2009 20:01:28 -0000	[current revision number]
+++ /dev/null	1 Jan 1970 00:00:00 -0000
[... and then there's a minus before every line of the file]

Crucible can interpret those files as removed.
fields.summary: Show deleted files as red in left nav

fields.description:
It would be helpful to be able to configure a different set of Defect Classifications for each project in Crucible.  Maybe the configuration could be similar to JIRA's "Schemes", we could have Defect Classification Schemes and each project could pick which Scheme to use.

We would like to expand our use of Crucible to multiple other teams inside the organization, some of which would like to have a different set of Defect Classifications.
fields.summary: Configure Defect Classifications per Project
